blog.name: xochiquetzl
blog.title: A bloodthirsty, troll-slaying Amazon Queen
blog.description: Also Xochiquetzl @ DW and AO3. writer, Ravenclaw, MOT, Snape fan, Kylo Ren fan, fandom old, fannish contrarian, studied at the Sith Academy, anti-racist transgender-supporting feminist, bisexual/cisgender panromantic demisexual/queer.  She/her/hers. The Q in LGBTQIA stands for Queer and the A stands for Asexual. Please don't follow me if you're a minor; I am old and post adult things.  Anti culture is toxic and I will unfollow you over it. Your hate mail will be graded.

summary:
ATTENTION FIC WRITING AND ART DRAWING
CRITTERS! Sign-up are now open for the first
annual Critmas Exchange! What is Critmas...
caption:
ATTENTION FIC WRITING AND ART DRAWING CRITTERS!

Sign-up are now open for the first annual Critmas Exchange!

What is Critmas Exhchange?

Critmas Exchange is a fanworks (fanfic and fanart) gift exchange for the Critical Role fandom run via the Archive of Our Own (AO3).

How it works: Participants sign-up to write a story, or create a piece of art according to the specifications of another participant. In return they will also receive a story or piece of art created for them by another participant.

More detailed explanations of Exchange rules and requirements can be found on AO3 HERE

On Dreamwidth HERE

An easy to read version of the tag set (what you can request and offer from) is available HERE

If you’d like to take part in this exchange, you can find the sign-up form HERE

Sign-ups close November 21st at midnight EST

Questions, comments, suggestions or need help figuring out how it works? Leave them here on Tumblr, drop them on the post on the Dreamwidth Community or stop by the Discord Channel.

blog.name: armourofagathys
blog.description: hi i'm jamie i'm 26 and this is my cr blog

summary: my fjord thoughts/theories no one asked for (spoilers c2e41, obviously)[[MORE]] I know that one of the big theories is that...
body:
my fjord thoughts/theories no one asked for

(spoilers c2e41, obviously)

I know that one of the big theories is that Fjord is just a Master Liar who’s been manipulating everyone, but I don’t 100% buy it. I think he’s just on a power trip.

He was always one of the more polite and reserved members of TMN, did the whole “face” thing, seemed like a responsible adult. It really seemed like he was trying to do genuine good, or at least genuine lawful. I don’t think that was an act.

But we know he was canonically an outcast, bullied kid, we know canonically that he never thought of himself as handsome, and was surprised when other people all of a sudden did - this is the exact personality of someone who would fucking lose their mind with a little bit of power.

Recently, he has:

  • Reveled in torturing and threatening Algar Dyomin way disproportionately for the crime he committed
  • Stole the boat (although he only gets partial responsibility for that one)
  • Tried to drown Avantika
  • Actual piracy, including the power trip of “oh, look how merciful we’re being! You wouldn’t want us to not be merciful, would you?”

I don’t think he understands there are consequences for any of this. His 7 WIS score would make sense. Low wisdom means you see the world as just existing around you - he doesn’t understand (or care) about how his actions are affecting people (both on a large scale, like giving Uk’otoa more power, and on a smaller scale, like ignoring Jester and sleeping with Avantika). I think he doesn’t realize how much of an effect he can have because he’s felt powerless for so long (another result of his bullied-outcast childhood).

The part of him that knows he’s getting carried away was the part that talked to Caleb, the conversation whose subtext boiled down to “kill me if I endanger anyone we care about.” But in doing this, he’s also taking the responsibility for his actions away from himself, and giving it to Caleb. If he does something bad, it’s not his fault, it’s Caleb’s (or Beau’s) fault for not stopping him.

I think Uk’otoa’s influence is corrupting Fjord. I think we knew the genuine Fjord before, even if he seemed super sketchy and untrustworthy at times. I don’t know if there’s a way for this to end well at all. I think getting closer to Uk’otoa and any new power will absolutely just make him more cruel and power-hungry. I wonder if maybe he’ll multiclass out of warlock and into something else, because doing anything to gain more power could be seriously dangerous.

Also Travis is doing a fucking great job and I love it. This sounds really critical of Fjord but he’s still my fave and I’d die for him. Thanks for coming to my ted talk

my fjord thoughts/theories no one asked for

(spoilers c2e41, obviously)

blog.name: critiquingsoul
blog.title: Critiquing soul
blog.description:
Critter, Student, odd hour sleeper leading to random musings. Is a sideblog | Avatar pic by 
frogclabon

title: Quick Character Study - Caleb/Phillipe
body:
Ohmygodohmygod I just realised something. Liam’s a genius of a player. Ok that wasn’t a realisation but still. 

I kept turning it over in my head, why didnt Caleb prepare Fireball, the most dangerous offensive spell he had in his arsenal when going into the Yuan-Ti temple? As a player and as a character, he would have anticipated a great deal of danger and when push comes to shove, you would definitely want a big-ass fireball ready. 

I am convinced that Caleb is playing the long game; for the first time in identity management, he keeps to Phillipe as a name, breaking out a Caleb when he can’t let it slide. He plays up a unassuming and subservient manner, as a mere member of Captain Fjord’s crew. He has been very, very wary and observant as to when Avantika is around and does his best to appear unthreatening or incompetent (like when he appeared to be unaware of the piracy going on in Ep41 and waiting on Avantika’s orders, instead of rushing to rescue Fjord). So it is my inference, that he did not want to bust out his trump card(s) in front of Avantika. 

Because make no mistake, in the larger scheme of things, Caleb Widogast is the most dangerous person aboard the Squalleater. He can, in the span of half a minute, unload 4 Fireballs (31d6 AOE fire damage), inside a wooden ship packed with gunpowder. Even if it isn’t outright annihilated, it would be gutted, crippled and defanged.  And now at Level 7, there exists the possibility that the rest of the Nein evacuate to the Mistake, pack it with loyal crew members while Caleb and Jester stay on the Squalleater. Caleb unleashes the fire, and Jester Dimension Door’s them out (500 feet or 167m). (Fjord’s Thunder Step is a lesser version with shorter range, but also does damage and can ‘port someone with them). The only thing that remains is to silence all witnesses and kill Avantika in a climatic duel.

For Fjord and Avantika, the power dynamic has Avantika at a clear advantage, her holding the information, the favour of Uk’otoa, the loyalty of a larger crew, ownership of ships, wealth and contacts. For Caleb and Avantika, Caleb has the advantage of initiative, deliberately shrouding himself in mediocrity and waiting for the opportune moment. I believe he has a handle on Avantika; he sees the zealotry and pride in the Captain, the surety of purpose that also blinds, because he was once that fanatical, that cocky and sure of ultimate victory. 

I believe that Caleb’s trauma is also preventing him from actively seeking to enact any violent escape plan. The scenario of nuking a whole ship with dozens of souls, alongside the Captain, is not a black and white issue of “they’re the enemy, they must die”. Not for Caleb, who actively distrusts his own judgement and is waiting for the group to make up their minds. For now, the Mighty Nein are in a holding pattern, leaving Fjord the space to make the calls. I do not know when any of them will snap and say, Fuck this shit I’m out, who’s with me? 

As a final speculation, I’m just thinking of who would be the most enthusiastic to get out (might also depend on who is proposing). Nott has no liking for piracy, beyond the gunnery, since it involves too much water and outright coercion rather than thievery. Caduceus is literally being taken in the opposite direction, both physically and morally from where he’d like to be, but has chosen to adapt for now. Beau likes the freedom of no laws, but is rightfully concerned about god summoning (she would most definitely snitch on Avantika to Plank King, or even start a smear campaign). Jester would say yes as long as they get to piss on Avantika in any way, which would put her in conflict if Fjord opposes. Yasha is a little too undeveloped as a character to pick apart and analyse, but I would hazard a guess that the unhealthy power dynamic chafes. Finally, Fjord. Hmmmm..I’d leave that to another post I think, this one is getting a little off topic.

To end off, I am almost certain, that with sufficient planning and will, the Mighty Nein have the means to do a runner and get off relatively safe in the short term. They just need to realize it.
body_abstract: Ohmygodohmygod I just realised something. Liam’s a genius of a player. Ok that wasn’t a realisation but still.

Even if it isn’t outright annihilated, it would be gutted, crippled and defanged.  And now at Level 7, there exists the possibility that the rest of the Nein evacuate to the Mistake, pack it with loyal crew members while Caleb and Jester stay on the Squalleater. Caleb unleashes the fire, and Jester Dimension Door’s them out (500 feet or 167m). (Fjord’s Thunder Step is a lesser version with shorter range, but also does damage and can ‘port someone with them). The only thing that remains is to silence all witnesses and kill Avantika in a climatic duel.

For Fjord and Avantika, the power dynamic has Avantika at a clear advantage, her holding the information, the favour of Uk’otoa, the loyalty of a larger crew, ownership of ships, wealth and contacts. For Caleb and Avantika, Caleb has the advantage of initiative, deliberately shrouding himself in mediocrity and waiting for the opportune moment. I believe he has a handle on Avantika; he sees the zealotry and pride in the Captain, the surety of purpose that also blinds, because he was once that fanatical, that cocky and sure of ultimate victory. 

I believe that Caleb’s trauma is also preventing him from actively seeking to enact any violent escape plan. The scenario of nuking a whole ship with dozens of souls, alongside the Captain, is not a black and white issue of “they’re the enemy, they must die”. Not for Caleb, who actively distrusts his own judgement and is waiting for the group to make up their minds. For now, the Mighty Nein are in a holding pattern, leaving Fjord the space to make the calls. I do not know when any of them will snap and say, Fuck this shit I’m out, who’s with me? 

As a final speculation, I’m just thinking of who would be the most enthusiastic to get out (might also depend on who is proposing). Nott has no liking for piracy, beyond the gunnery, since it involves too much water and outright coercion rather than thievery. Caduceus is literally being taken in the opposite direction, both physically and morally from where he’d like to be, but has chosen to adapt for now. Beau likes the freedom of no laws, but is rightfully concerned about god summoning (she would most definitely snitch on Avantika to Plank King, or even start a smear campaign). Jester would say yes as long as they get to piss on Avantika in any way, which would put her in conflict if Fjord opposes. Yasha is a little too undeveloped as a character to pick apart and analyse, but I would hazard a guess that the unhealthy power dynamic chafes. Finally, Fjord. Hmmmm..I’d leave that to another post I think, this one is getting a little off topic.

To end off, I am almost certain, that with sufficient planning and will, the Mighty Nein have the means to do a runner and get off relatively safe in the short term. They just need to realize it.

trail.content_raw:
Ohmygodohmygod I just realised something. Liam’s a genius of a player. Ok that wasn’t a realisation but still. 

[[MORE]]

I kept turning it over in my head, why didnt Caleb prepare Fireball, the most dangerous offensive spell he had in his arsenal when going into the Yuan-Ti temple? As a player and as a character, he would have anticipated a great deal of danger and when push comes to shove, you would definitely want a big-ass fireball ready. 

I am convinced that Caleb is playing the long game; for the first time in identity management, he keeps to Phillipe as a name, breaking out a Caleb when he can’t let it slide. He plays up a unassuming and subservient manner, as a mere member of Captain Fjord’s crew. He has been very, very wary and observant as to when Avantika is around and does his best to appear unthreatening or incompetent (like when he appeared to be unaware of the piracy going on in Ep41 and waiting on Avantika’s orders, instead of rushing to rescue Fjord). So it is my inference, that he did not want to bust out his trump card(s) in front of Avantika. 

Because make no mistake, in the larger scheme of things, Caleb Widogast is the most dangerous person aboard the Squalleater. He can, in the span of half a minute, unload 4 Fireballs (31d6 AOE fire damage), inside a wooden ship packed with gunpowder. Even if it isn’t outright annihilated, it would be gutted, crippled and defanged.  And now at Level 7, there exists the possibility that the rest of the Nein evacuate to the Mistake, pack it with loyal crew members while Caleb and Jester stay on the Squalleater. I believe that Caleb’s trauma is also preventing him from actively seeking to enact any violent escape plan. The scenario of nuking a whole ship with dozens of souls, alongside the Captain, is not a black and white issue of “they’re the enemy, they must die”. Not for Caleb, who actively distrusts his own judgement and is waiting for the group to make up their minds. For now, the Mighty Nein are in a holding pattern, leaving Fjord the space to make the calls. I do not know when any of them will snap and say, Fuck this shit I’m out, who’s with me? 

As a final speculation, I’m just thinking of who would be the most enthusiastic to get out (might also depend on who is proposing). Nott has no liking for piracy, beyond the gunnery, since it involves too much water and outright coercion rather than thievery. Caduceus is literally being taken in the opposite direction, both physically and morally from where he’d like to be, but has chosen to adapt for now. Beau likes the freedom of no laws, but is rightfully concerned about god summoning (she would most definitely snitch on Avantika to Plank King, or even start a smear campaign). Jester would say yes as long as they get to piss on Avantika in any way, which would put her in conflict if Fjord opposes. Yasha is a little too undeveloped as a character to pick apart and analyse, but I would hazard a guess that the unhealthy power dynamic chafes. Finally, Fjord. Hmmmm..I’d leave that to another post I think, this one is getting a little off topic.

To end off, I am almost certain, that with sufficient planning and will, the Mighty Nein have the means to do a runner and get off relatively safe in the short term. They just need to realize it.

Fjord: What happened to my first wife?
Jester: Nothing you...

blog.description: Friendly reminder: TERFs can choke :) I'm Skylar. They/Them pronouns. Asexual and proud of it, genderqueer, lesbian. I tag what people ask me to, including #critical role, and #actuallyadhd. If you see any untaged Critical Role or ADHD posts, tell me so I can fix it. If I reblog from a transphobe, let me know so I can delete it.
